titleInfo.subTitle: Huel D. Perkins oral history interview, 2006

name.description: Huel D. Perkins was born in 1924 to John E. Perkins, Sr., and Velma Valeria Davis Perkins in Baton Rouge, La. He attended Southern University Laboratory School for elementary and high school, graduating in 1940. He attended Southern University for three years until he enlisted with the U.S. Navy to serve in World War II. After the war, Perkins completed his bachelor's degree at Southern University and went on to receive a master's and Ph.D. from Northwestern University. Perkins eventually returned to Baton Rouge and joined the faculty of Southern University where he taught music for twenty-seven years. In 1978, he accepted a position as assistant vice chancellor of academic affairs at Louisiana State University. Perkins continued his connection to LSU as executive assistant to Chancellor Bud Davis until 1989, when he also became a professor emeritus of humanities at LSU.

mods.abstract: Perkins discusses his education and goes into some detail on his family history. He discusses the educational opportunities available to African-American students in the Baton Rouge area in the 1930s and 1940s, including McKinley High and the three elementary schools for African-American children. He describes activities and sports he took part in in the community and through his church and school. He discusses some of the prominent leaders in the Baton Rouge African-American community. Perkins also discusses segregation, racism, African-American fraternities, and civil rights activism.
